text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday morning's Austrian newspapers:
DER STANDARD

- Conservative whip Andreas Khol says senior coalition partner the Social Democrats should not move alone in a bid to improve women's rights. About 800,000 Austrians signed a petition calling for more women's rights earlier this year.
- Austria will not be able to reduce greenhouse gases to the extent it agreed at the Toronto climate summit because regional and federal government cannot agree on joint measures.
- Do-It-Yourself chain bauMax plans to raise its turnover to 7.8 billion schillings this year. Bonus shares will be paid out on top of the dividend.

- The World Economic Forum ranked Austria only 27th in terms of competitiveness among the 53 largest industrial nations in 1997. Austria has fallen eight places since last year. The country's economic growth is only ranked 34th.
- Oil and chemicals group OMV's Hungarian unit OMV Hungaria reported losses of 35 million schillings even though turnover jumped 30 percent.
- Raiffeisen Zentralbank's operating profits jumped 22.3 percent to 2.6 billion schillings in 1996. The bank's eastern European subsidiaries accounted for over 50 percent of the profits.
DIE PRESSE
- Regional leaders of the conservative People's Party are against the national party's plans to join Nato as quickly as possible. They are also opposed to a new law restricting politicians' pay.
- Current Interior Minister Karl Schloegl and his predecessor Caspar Einem were unaware that police had found numerous arms depots of the Soviet secret service KGB.
- Chancellor Viktor Klima and Finance Minister Rudolf Edlinger say the government plans to raise public pensions in 1998 by 1.5 percent at the most.
- Former Justice Minister Egmont Foregger says the escape of the alleged Iranian murderers of three Kurdish leaders in 1989 happened due to "unfortunate circumstances".
- The government's new export offensive plan is ready and will be discussed at the government's convention at the beginning of June.
- The number of new car registrations fell in April.
KURIER
- Austria is on the search for alleged investments of former Zairian dictator Mobutu.
- The People's Party plans to discuss the abolition of the country's conscription should Austria join NATO.

- Raiffeisen Zentralbank wants to take over all the available shares of Bank Austria in Investkredit and Kontrollbank. The bank favours insurance holding BARC to buy the government's stake in postal savings bank PSK. However, it says it would also participate itself should this not be possible.
SALZBURGER NACHRICHTEN
- The People's Party say a Social Democrat plan to include all workers in the social security system would cost jobs. About 165,000 Austrians would have to start paying social security fees.
WIRTSCHAFTSBLATT
- The government has not yet started paying out money to subsidise technological research because necessary laws are not in place.
